dc:description: The PRG4 gene is located on chromosome 1 at 1q31.1 and encodes the proteoglycan 4 protein, which is a lubricating component of synovial fluid and acts as a boundary lubricant at the cartilage surface. It also has a chondroprotective feature and acts by preventing protein deposition from the synovial fluid onto the cartilage surface. PRG4 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive, camptodactyly-arthropathy-coxa vara-pericarditis syndrome in 1999 (Marcelino et al., 1999 PMID 10545950). This is a rare disorder characterized by early onset camptodactyly, non-inflammatory arthropathy with synovial hyperplasia, and progressive coxa vara deformity. Pericardial or pleural effusions have also been reported in some patients. Camptodactyly is usually the first finding in the majority of patients, followed by swellings of the wrists, knees, and elbows around the age of 4 years. Large joint involvement and age of onset of pain varies among patients. Severe hip and vertebral involvement developed after 20 years of age. At least 7 unique loss of function variants have been reported in literature. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 6 probands from 3 publications (Marcelino et al., 1999 PMID 10545950; Peters et al., 2016 PMID 27224999; Yilmaz et al., 2018 PMID 29397575). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in three families. One clan comprising five families reported 12 affected family members, five of whom were homozygous for the same variant (PMID 29397575). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The mechanism for disease is biallelic loss of function. This gene-disease relationship is supported by two independent Prg4 KO mouse modes that recapitulate the human disease (Rhee et al., 2005 PMID 15719068; Coles et al., 2010 PMID 20191580). In summary, there is definitive evidence to support the relationship between PRG4 and autosomal recessive camptodactyly-arthropathy-coxa vara-pericarditis syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date April 27th, 2021 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: At 2 months of age, joints of PRG4-/- mice were significantly different from WT and heterozygous mice. Mutant mice exhibited synovial hyperplasia that progressed with age, subintimal fibrosis, proteinaceous deposits on the cartilage surface, irregular cartilage surface, and endochondral growth plates. By 4 months of age, mutant mice showed swelling of the ankle joints, flexion deformity of the hind paws, and developed an abnormal hopping gait. At 9 months of age, the knee joint space in mutant mice was filled by a noninflammatory, hyperplastic synovium, and the articular cartilage surface was barely recognizable. Abnormal calcification was present in tendon sheaths and osteophytes with higher number of proliferating cells in synovium of mutant mice. These findings were further confirmed by ex vivo experiments on cultured synoviocytes of 4-month mutant mice. Prg4 -/- mice recaptulate many of the phenotypes found in patients, including joint swelling, abnormal gait, progressive synovial hyperplasia, abnormal cartilage surface, and eventual joint failure.
evidence.rdfs:label: PRG4 KO mouse model (exon 6 replaced)

evidence.dc:description: Synovial fluid from patients with CACP show no ability to lower friction in a latex-onglass bearing, which can be effectively lubricated by normal synovial fluid. Friction and elastic modulus in cartilage of Prg4 -/- KO and WT mice at ages 2, 4, 10, and 16 weeks exhibited significant changes in articular cartilage properties, including enlargement and roughening of the surface layer, irregularities in cartilage structure, and age-related changes in the compressive modulus. Cartilage of KO mice was also characterized by a pericellular loss of proteoglycans and delayed tidemark progression. This degenerative cartilage phenotype caused by the lack of PRG4 is similar to that observed clinically in patients. This model demonstrates structural and biomechanical changes in cartilage following gene KO.
evidence.rdfs:label: PRG4 KO mouse model

evidence.dc:description: As per Human atlas and GTEx, PRG4 is expressed in many tissues (adipose tissue, liver). PMID 10545950: Northern blot on human tissue demonstrated CACP mRNA expression in tissues including liver, lung and heart.

In mice, Prg4 is expressed after developing joints have begun to cavitate. At the early stages of this process, low levels of Prg4 expression are detected in cells near the newly formed joint surface and at later stages of morphogenesis, strong Prg4 expression is observed in cartilage surface cells (superficial zone chondrocytes) and in the newly forming synovium. Postnatally, strong expression of Prg4 persists in the surface chondrocytes and in synovial intimal cells (Fig 2).
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in mice

evidence.dc:description: Default score for two LoF variants is 3, subtract 0.5 for homozygosity and 0.5 for consanguinity. Total points 3-1=2.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family b
evidence.detectionMethod: Positional-candidate approach followed by sequencing of PRG4 gene using PCR and RT-PCR to amplify portions of PRG4 from patient-derived genomic DNA and mRNA

evidence.dc:description: Default score for two LoF variants is 3, subtract 0.5 for homozygosity and 0.5 for consanguinity. Total points 3-1=2.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family number 1/NG1620-1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Camptodactyly of hands and feet, arthropathy of wrists, elbows, knees, ankles, coxa vara, flattened femoral heads, short femoral neck, osteoporosis, increased lumbar lordosis, pain, MVP, and MR.
Family history - 12 affected members (5 described). See Table 1.

evidence.dc:description: Default score for two LoF variants is 3, subtract 0.5 for homozygosity and 0.5 for consanguinity. Total points 3-1=2.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Flexion contracture of the right-hand little finger since infancy, progressively swollen and painful knees, wrists, elbows and ankles since the age of three, and swollen face. She also suffered from recurrent respiratory infections, camptodactyly of her right fifth finger, mild curvature of her left index finger, swollen ankles and knees, extension of both elbows was limited, enlarged liver, pleural and pericardial effusion, hepatomegaly, portal hypertension, PLE, constrictive pericarditis, coxa vara, peri-articular osteopenia and flattened metacarpal, and phalangeal joints.
Fecal analysis showed an increased alpha antitrypsin clearance, suggesting PLE.
Family history- Her father and his sister also experienced similar childhood-onset joint complaints. The father had been diagnosed with JIA as a child.
